p: Accessibility to highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) has dramatically improved the life expectancy of HIV-infected individuals, however studies have shown that HAART is associated with an increased prevalence of non-communicable diseases, including type 2 diabetes [ 1]. Thus, Brown et al. [ 2] observed that the prevalence of diabetes was up to four fold higher in HIV-infected men exposed to HAART compared to HIV-negative men. A recent meta-analysis confirms the strong association between the use of anti-retroviral therapy (ART) and increased risk for diabetes [ 3]. Furthermore, HIV-infected individuals have been found to have higher rates of metabolic syndrome, dyslipidaemia and lipodystrophy when compared to subjects without HIV infection [ 4].
